text:
Hmmm... I wonder what platforms do people use Julia on
   :windows95:, :apple: or  :linux: ？

elements.text: Hmmm... I wonder what platforms do people use Julia on

text:
I find it hard to believe that the numbers don't add to 100, for choice of OS....
Which means, someone uses Julia on multiple OS, which is kinda rare....

elements.text:
I find it hard to believe that the numbers don't add to 100, for choice of OS....
Which means, someone uses Julia on multiple OS, which is kinda rare....

text:
<@U680THK2S> You're a rare person:rolling_on_the_floor_laughing:
How'd your describe your freebsd experience compared to whatever you used before？:slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: How'd your describe your freebsd experience compared to whatever you used before？

text:
> Which means, someone uses Julia on multiple OS, which is kinda rare
Actually, I don't think it's all that rare. I run Julia on Linux (desktop and AWS EC2 for work), macOS (laptop), and FreeBSD (anywhere I can install it). I think at least the combination of work OS and personal OS is likely fairly common.

elements.text: Which means, someone uses Julia on multiple OS, which is kinda rare

Actually, I don't think it's all that rare. I run Julia on Linux (desktop and AWS EC2 for work), macOS (laptop), and FreeBSD (anywhere I can install it). I think at least the combination of work OS and personal OS is likely fairly common.

text: I keep thinking about switching to BSD from Mac

elements.text: I keep thinking about switching to BSD from Mac

text:
I do understand macOS + Linux...
I don't understand why someone would use Julia in Windows with Linux (unless forced by their workplce to do so)

elements.text:
I do understand macOS + Linux...
I don't understand why someone would use Julia in Windows with Linux (unless forced by their workplce to do so)

text: I find it kind of funny that among Julia users, linux+ppc is as common as linux on a whole is for desktop

elements.text: I find it kind of funny that among Julia users, linux+ppc is as common as linux on a whole is for desktop

text:
I don't know about how stuff works in the industry, but I hear that employees are forced to work on a specific OS in some companies
The very thought annoys and scares me:slightly_frowning_face:

elements.text:
I don't know about how stuff works in the industry, but I hear that employees are forced to work on a specific OS in some companies
The very thought annoys and scares me

text: I see people all the time using Windows and Linux with whatever software they use. Usually at my university most PhD students just use windows in their personal computers because that is their preference but if they want to run something in a computing cluster they inevitably have to use linux. I am in a similar situation but macOs and Linux in my case.

elements.text: I see people all the time using Windows and Linux with whatever software they use. Usually at my university most PhD students just use windows in their personal computers because that is their preference but if they want to run something in a computing cluster they inevitably have to use linux. I am in a similar situation but macOs and Linux in my case.

text: Oh yeah, I guess I also use Julia on Linux on the cluster but didn’t even think to click the Linux button at first.

elements.text: Oh yeah, I guess I also use Julia on Linux on the cluster but didn’t even think to click the Linux button at first.

text:
It'll take time for me to understand why'd someone keep a bloaty and clunky OS as Windows, as their personal preference
Like, any Windows user here would like to tell why they prefer Windows over other options?

elements.text:
It'll take time for me to understand why'd someone keep a bloaty and clunky OS as Windows, as their personal preference
Like, any Windows user here would like to tell why they prefer Windows over other options?

text: A coworker of mine switched from Linux to Windows for his personal computer because he could run Linux software in WSL and just about everything else in Windows. I know a common theme for people who run Windows is that they want to be able to run games.

elements.text: A coworker of mine switched from Linux to Windows for his personal computer because he could run Linux software in WSL and just about everything else in Windows. I know a common theme for people who run Windows is that they want to be able to run games.

text: honestly at this point, I haven't had a game recently not work on linux (thanks to Wine/Proton). I know not everything works perfectly, but at least for what I play, I've had no complaints
